comments.body: Might be useful to add a comment on why we don’t go via `dev_env` on unix. Do you know why exactly this is causing problems or is this just a case of trial and error and nixpkgs seems to avoid this?

I'm not exactly sure what caused the latest failure. However, `dev_env_tool` introduces an additional layer of indirection through symbolic links. We've had a couple issues with that in the past, e.g. https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/issues/2959. This seems to be more problematic for `node_repositories` than in other use-cases of `dev_env_tool`. So, removing that layer of indirection may well avoid the issue.

comments.body: I guess there is no easier way to get a package from Hackage that isn’t in Stackage? This seems rather verbose and annoying to maintain.
Actually I’m not sure why we can’t modify the `stack-snapshot.yaml` file for these?

The reason is that this is an executable target, not a library target. That's what I meant by
> Binaries are not generated by stack_snapshot, so these are defined in WORKSPACE. Their library dependencies are supplied using the stack_snapshot.

I.e. the library `@stackage//:hpp` is generated by `stack_snapshot`, but the binary is defined separately.
Ah I see makes sense, thanks for the explanation! That’s what I get for not reading the docs closely :slightly_smiling_face:

comments.body: The reason why all of the hashes changed is that I switched `hazel_github_external` from `.zip` to `.tar.gz` since Bazel falls over on the symlink in gRPC-haskell otherwise (https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/2656 has the same error but is closed for some reason).
`hazel_hackage` can also take a `patches` argument. See e.g. `network` above.
Good point, thanks! I changed it.
